file_metadata.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]
file_metadata.title: Triple-negative breast cancer cells activate sensory neurons via TRPV1 to drive nerve outgrowth and tumor progression

chunks.text: The tumor microenvironment in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is characterized by increased sensory nerve density, which contributes to cancer progression. The origin of these nerves and the mechanisms driving innervation are not well understood. This study uses retrograde labeling to show that mammary tumors have increased nerves from the dorsal root ganglia. TNBC cells trigger stress and activation markers in neurons and induce firing in a TRPV1-dependent manner. In vitro, TNBC cells promote sensory nerve outgrowth, which is blocked by Trpv1 knockout. c-Jun and IL-6 are identified as downstream effectors of TRPV1-mediated neurite outgrowth. In vivo, Trpv1 knockout mice show delayed tumor growth and reduced lung metastasis, suggesting TRPV1's critical role in tumor-nerve crosstalk and its potential as a therapeutic target.
chunks.chunk_summary: TNBC cells activate sensory neurons via TRPV1, promoting nerve outgrowth and tumor progression, while Trpv1 knockout reduces these effects.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: The tumor microenvironment (TME) plays a crucial role in cancer progression. Increased peripheral nerve density is observed in various solid tumors, including breast cancer. These nerves, including sympathetic, parasympathetic, and sensory nerves, can both promote and suppress tumor growth. Understanding the mechanisms driving tumor innervation could offer new strategies to combat metastatic disease. Breast cancer, particularly TNBC, is associated with increased sensory nerve fiber density and poorer prognosis. Co-injection of TNBC cells and sensory neurons increases tumor growth and metastasis, while denervation reduces progression. Sensory nerve outgrowth into tumors is regulated by factors like neurotrophic factors, axon guidance molecules, ECM components, and bioelectric signals. While these pathways are well-studied in development and injury, their role in tumor-induced nerve growth is less understood.
chunks.chunk_summary: The tumor microenvironment, particularly increased nerve density, plays a critical role in cancer progression, especially in TNBC, and understanding the mechanisms involved could lead to new therapeutic strategies.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: Sensory nerves can regenerate in adulthood, suggesting that increased innervation in TNBC is driven by outgrowth from adjacent healthy tissue. This growth is regulated by extrinsic cues, including neurotrophic factors (NGF, BDNF), axon guidance molecules (semaphorins, netrins), ECM components, and bioelectric signals. These cues act through receptors and ion channels, triggering intracellular pathways that activate transcriptional programs for neurite extension. While these pathways are well-characterized in development and injury, their role in tumor-induced nerve growth is less explored. Studies have shown that deletion of SLIT2 or inhibition of VEGF or NGF receptors reduces sensory nerve density in TNBC models. However, the direct effects of tumor cells on sensory nerves and the downstream neuronal mechanisms remain poorly understood.
chunks.topic: Sensory nerve regeneration and tumor innervation
chunks.chunk_summary: Sensory nerve outgrowth into tumors is regulated by various factors, but the direct effects of tumor cells and downstream mechanisms are not fully understood.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: TRPV1, a non-selective cation channel on peripheral sensory neurons, detects noxious stimuli. Its activation leads to calcium and sodium influx, membrane depolarization, and pain signal transmission. TRPV1 also contributes to neurite outgrowth and regeneration through calcium-dependent pathways. Many TRPV1 activators and sensitizers, such as heat, acidification, inflammatory mediators, and NGF, are present in the TNBC TME. High TRPV1 expression in TNBC correlates with poor patient survival. This study hypothesizes that tumor-secreted factors activate TRPV1 on sensory nerves, triggering regenerative signaling and neurite outgrowth into the TME.
chunks.topic: TRPV1 and its role in sensory neurons
chunks.chunk_summary: TRPV1, activated by factors present in the TNBC TME, is hypothesized to promote sensory nerve outgrowth into the tumor.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: Mammary tumors show increased innervation from dorsal root ganglia (DRG). Retrograde tracer Dil was injected into the mammary fat pad or tumor of FVB control and MMTV-PyMT mice at different ages. Dil-labeled DRG neurons increased in MMTV-PyMT mice at 9 and 12 weeks, indicating early sensory nerve recruitment during tumor progression. T8 to L2 DRGs were the primary source of innervation, corresponding to the spinal levels supplying the lower mammary glands.
chunks.topic: DRG nerve origin in mammary tumors
chunks.chunk_summary: Retrograde tracing reveals increased innervation of mammary tumors from T8-L2 DRGs during tumor progression in MMTV-PyMT mice.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: TNBC cells induce stress and activation responses in sensory neurons. DRG from tumor-bearing mice and DRG co-cultured with TNBC cells showed increased nuclear ATF3 and cFos expression, markers of stress and neuronal activity. Calca, encoding CGRP (involved in pain signaling), was also upregulated in DRG from tumor-bearing mice and in co-cultures with human TNBC cells. These findings indicate that TNBC tumors stimulate stress and activation pathways in sensory neurons.
chunks.chunk_summary: TNBC cells induce stress and activation markers (ATF3, cFos, CGRP) in sensory neurons both in vivo and in vitro.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: TNBC cells promote sensory neuron growth in a TRPV1-dependent manner. Co-culturing wild-type DRG with TNBC cells or their conditioned media enhanced neuritogenesis, neurite diameter, neuron cell body area, and neurite bundling. However, these effects were abrogated or attenuated in DRG from Trpv1 knockout mice, indicating TRPV1's role in TNBC-induced neurite outgrowth.
chunks.chunk_summary: TNBC cells promote sensory neuron growth in vitro, and this effect is dependent on TRPV1.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: In 3D hydrogels, TNBC cells promote directional neurite outgrowth from DRG explants. Wild-type DRG explants showed increased neurite density towards TNBC cells, while Trpv1 knockout DRG did not exhibit this directional growth. This confirms that tumor cells induce morphological changes in sensory neurons associated with increased outgrowth and innervation.
chunks.chunk_summary: TNBC cells promote directional neurite outgrowth from DRG explants in a TRPV1-dependent manner in 3D hydrogels.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: TNBC cells activate sensory neurons via TRPV1. Co-culturing DRG with TNBC cells increased TRPV1 expression.  Trpv1 knockout neurons did not show increased cFos or CGRP expression when co-cultured with TNBC cells.  TNBC cells increased the firing rate and decreased the interspike interval of wild-type DRG neurons on microelectrode arrays, while Trpv1 knockout neurons showed decreased firing. These data suggest that TNBC cells drive increased electrical activity in DRG neurons via TRPV1.
chunks.chunk_summary: TNBC cells activate sensory neurons and increase their electrical activity through TRPV1 signaling.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: IL-6 acts downstream of TRPV1 to promote neurite outgrowth. RNA sequencing data from DRG co-cultured with TNBC cells showed upregulation of genes involved in cell proliferation, migration, and developmental processes. c-Jun, a transcription factor activated downstream of TRPV1, was highly enriched, and its target gene Il6, a mediator of neurite outgrowth, was significantly upregulated.  In vivo and in vitro experiments confirmed increased cJun expression in DRG from tumor-bearing mice and in DRG co-cultured with TNBC cells. This increase was abrogated in Trpv1 knockout DRG.  Il6 knockout DRG did not show significant changes in neurite outgrowth when co-cultured with TNBC cells or their conditioned media. These findings suggest that TRPV1 activation promotes neurite outgrowth through cJun-mediated IL-6 signaling.
chunks.topic: IL-6 and c-Jun in neurite outgrowth
chunks.chunk_summary: IL-6, regulated by c-Jun downstream of TRPV1, promotes neurite outgrowth in response to TNBC cells.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: Trpv1 knockout delays tumor progression in vivo. PY8119 TNBC cells injected into Trpv1 knockout mice resulted in smaller tumors and reduced lung metastasis compared to wild-type mice. This highlights the importance of TRPV1 in tumor growth and metastasis.
chunks.chunk_summary: Trpv1 knockout in mice delays TNBC tumor growth and reduces lung metastasis.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: The mechanisms driving tumor innervation are poorly understood. This study shows that TNBC cells activate sensory neurons via TRPV1, leading to increased activity markers, bioelectric activity, and neurite outgrowth. This is mediated by TRPV1-dependent c-Jun signaling and downstream IL-6. Trpv1 knockout reduces tumor growth and metastasis. This study provides a comprehensive description of tumor cell-driven effects on sensory nerves and identifies potential strategies to suppress innervation and reduce the pro-tumorigenic effects of nerves.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study demonstrates that TNBC cells activate sensory neurons and promote tumor progression via TRPV1, suggesting TRPV1 inhibition as a potential therapeutic strategy.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: TNBC cells activate sensory neurons via TRPV1, increasing activity markers and bioelectric activity, similar to nerve regeneration after injury.  Tumor-bearing mice and in vitro cultures showed increased cFos and CGRP, abrogated in Trpv1 knockout neurons.  TNBC cells increased firing rate and decreased interspike interval in DRG neurons, potentially through synaptic-like mechanisms or local pro-regenerative cues. Future studies are needed to determine the specific mechanisms involved.
chunks.chunk_summary: TNBC cells activate sensory neurons and alter their bioelectric activity, mimicking nerve regeneration responses, potentially through various mechanisms including synaptic-like interactions.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: Some effects of tumor cells on nerves are contact-dependent, while others are not. Conditioned media and direct co-culture enhanced neurite outgrowth, but only direct co-culture increased neurite fasciculation, a TRPV1-independent process potentially mediated by adhesion molecules or ECM stiffening. In 3D hydrogels, secreted factors drove TRPV1-dependent neurite extension. Conditioned media had varied effects on bioelectric activity, suggesting different modes of interaction between tumor cells and neurons.  The tumor microenvironment provides various cues that activate TRPV1, and direct contact may enable additional interactions beyond TRPV1 activation. Future studies are needed to dissect the contribution of individual signals to sensory innervation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Tumor cells influence nerve outgrowth through both contact-dependent and -independent mechanisms, involving various factors including TRPV1, adhesion molecules, and ECM properties.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: TRPV1 plays a critical role in tumor cell-driven neuron activation and neurite outgrowth, and its knockout reduces tumor growth and metastasis. TRPV1 inhibitors, initially developed for pain and inflammation, showed promise but were halted due to adverse effects. New approaches, including modality-selective antagonists, peripherally restricted compounds, and localized delivery, are being developed to overcome these limitations.  Further development of safer TRPV1 inhibitors and identification of specific tumor-derived TRPV1 activators may lead to new therapeutic strategies.
chunks.chunk_summary: TRPV1 inhibition is a potential therapeutic strategy to disrupt tumor-nerve interactions, and new approaches are being developed to overcome the limitations of earlier TRPV1 inhibitors.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: This study used mice housed under standard conditions with access to food, water, and a 12/12 light cycle. All animal procedures were approved by the Tufts University Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee.
chunks.chunk_summary: Mice were housed under standard conditions, and all procedures were ethically approved.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: Dorsal root ganglia (DRG) were dissected from mice following euthanasia.  DRG were processed for immunofluorescence imaging, RNA extraction, 2D cell culture, or 3D explant culture.
chunks.chunk_summary: DRG were dissected from mice and processed for various downstream applications.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: The retrograde tracer Dil was injected into the mammary fat pad or tumor of FVB and MMTV-PyMT mice at different ages. After three days, DRG were dissected, dissociated, and plated. Dil-labeled neurons were visualized and scored to assess innervation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Retrograde tracing with Dil was used to assess DRG innervation of mammary tumors.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: DRG were collected for immunofluorescence staining or RNA extraction. For immunofluorescence, DRG sections were stained with antibodies against ATF3, cFos, cJun, and β3-tubulin. Nuclear fluorescence intensity was quantified. For qPCR, RNA was extracted from DRG, cDNA was synthesized, and qPCR was performed for Calca and Gapdh.
chunks.chunk_summary: DRG were analyzed by immunofluorescence staining for protein expression and by qPCR for gene expression.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]

chunks.text: Cell lines MCF10A and MDA-MB-231 were used.  Additional details on cell culture methods were not provided in this excerpt.
chunks.chunk_summary: MCF10A and MDA-MB-231 cell lines were used in the study.
chunks.authors: ["Hanan Bloomgren", "Savannah R. Parker", "Audrey L. Pierce", "Wesley Clawson", "Mallory M. Caron", "Thomas Gerton", "Ankit Pandey", "Thanh T. Le", "Toloupe Adewumi", "Charlotte Kuperwasser", "Michael Levin", "Madeleine J. Oudin"]
